presentation.title: Aesthetic viewsheds
presentation.runninghead: Values resulting from scenic views of ecosystems.
presentation.description: Aesthetic values are typically defined as the value derived from views or proximity to open space. These values often accrue to housing or property values and are often measured using hedonic pricing. Homeowners typically gain some combination of benefits through sensory enjoyment of views of nearby open space, proximity to open space for recreation, or privacy. This storyline maps ecosytem service provision, use, and flows for aesthetic viewsheds, including the type and quality of views, location and type of housing, the presence of features that block or degrade view quality, and flow models to connect beneficiaries to high quality views via a line-of-sight model.

page.name: Aesthetic viewshed assessment
page.title: Introduction
page.description: This storyline considers the contribution of ecosystems toward providing high-quality views and their impact on property values. The source model maps areas that contain high-quality views, the sink model maps areas with objects that degrade views, and the use model maps the location of homeowners. By combining these maps with a line of sight model, actual view quality and its potential impact on property values can be analyzed. In the recreation module, a similar set of models can be used to map and value viewsheds as they contribute to recreational experiences, such as on trails, mountain summits, or scenic drives.

page.name: Scenic vegetation type
page.title: Scenic vegetation type
page.description:
The presence of aesthetically pleasing land cover types, such as forests or riparian areas, which can be important in arid environments where green vegetation is scarcer and may be more highly valued than in humid environments.

Representation

page.name: Potential view quality
page.title: Potential view quality
page.description:
The quality of a potential view from residences.

Role in models

This is the output of the viewshed source model, and estimates the relative quality of different areas in providing aesthetically pleasing views, based on relevant input data.

Representation

The data are in abstract units from 0-100, representing relative suitability of different parts of the landscape to provide aesthetically pleasing views. As the output of the models is probabilistic, each point contains the probability distribution for potential view quality. The distribution can be visualized by clicking on the map; the mean value and the coefficient of variation are reported along with the probabilities.

Source

This map has been computed at your request by a Bayesian model built and calibrated by the ARIES server for the selected area.

The distribution can be visualized by clicking on the map; the mean value and the coefficient of variation are reported along with the probabilities.

page.name: Possible views
page.title: Possible views
page.description:
*Possible flow maps* show the path that the carrier of the service would take if it was not intercepted by sinks. As such it considers source and use models and shows the maximum amount of flow.
For provisioning services, this corresponds to the maximum potential benefit; for preventive services, the maximum potential damage.
This map shows the flow of views from natural areas toward homeowners when not accounting for sinks.
page.see-also: Aesthetic viewshed and proximity model details from the ARIES website

page.name: Visible natural beauty
page.title: Visible natural beauty
page.description:
*Possible source maps*, generated through flow analysis, show which specific sources actually generate carriers that reach users, independent of the existence of sinks but taking into account use values and the carrier flow paths. Even in the absence of sinks, not all of a source quantity can actually reach users, because of the route that an ecosystem service carrier moves across the landscape.
For provisioning services, this corresponds to the source of benefits that has the potential of being actually useful. For preventive services, this corresponds to the sources that could actually cause damage to people. The location and strength of sinks determines how much of the source actually reaches the users.
This map shows open space providing views when accounting for lines of sight and the location of homeowners but not visual blight.
page.see-also: Aesthetic viewshed and proximity model details from the ARIES website

page.name: Homeowners with possible views
page.title: Homeowners with possible views
page.description:
*Possible use maps* show the locations of users that can receive a benefit due to flow connections with a source of an ecosystem service carrier, but may or may not actually receive the carrier due to the action of sinks.
For provisioning services, potential use identifies areas where it is physically possible for a benefit to be received. For preventive services, potential use identifies areas that may be damaged by a detrimental carrier if sinks do not prevent such damage.
This map shows homeowners benefiting from views when sources of high-quality views and their flow paths are accounted for, but visual blight is not.
page.see-also: Aesthetic viewshed and proximity model details from the ARIES website

page.name: Actual views
page.title: Actual view flow
page.description:
*Actual flow maps* show the flow paths that deliver actual services to beneficiaries. These are selected from the total flow density to only show these flow paths that are not depleted by sinks and actually reach users.
For provisioning services, these flow paths deliver valuable benefits to the users and the density is proportional to the value accrued. For preventive services, the flow paths show how much of the carrier reaches users, delivering actual damage.
This map shows the actual flow of aesthetic views from natural areas toward homeowners, when accounting for sinks and flow paths.
page.see-also: Aesthetic viewshed and proximity model details from the ARIES website

page.name: Enjoyed views
page.title: Enjoyed views
page.description:
*Actual source maps* show sources that actually provide a service after accounting for sinks and flow dynamics.
For provisioning services, this is the amount and location of a benefit that actually provides benefits to the users. For preventive services, it shows where the actual damage came from. Source regions that provided a damaging carrier that was neutralized by sinks are not shown.
This map shows open space that actually provide views when accounting for flow paths, sinks, and the location of beneficiaries.
page.see-also: Aesthetic viewshed and proximity model details from the ARIES website

page.name: Relevant visual blight
page.title: Relevant visual blight
page.description:
*Actual sink maps* shows the sinks that actually contribute to depleting a service carrier given its flow patterns.
For provisioning services, such sinks reduce benefits to users compared to their possible value. For preventive services, such sinks provide the actual service because they prevent a damaging carrier from reaching users.
This map shows areas of visual blight located between visually valuable views and beneficiaries - features that actually degrade high quality views.
page.see-also: Aesthetic viewshed and proximity model details from the ARIES website

page.name: Homeowners with views
page.title: Homeowners with views
page.description:
*Actual use maps* show the level of use of a beneficial carrier for a provisioning service or damage caused by a detrimental carrier for a preventive service, for users.
This map shows homeowners who benefit from views when accounting for sources of views, sinks, and flow paths.
page.see-also: Aesthetic viewshed and proximity model details from the ARIES website

page.name: Homeowners without views
page.title: Homeowners without views
page.description:
*Inaccessible use maps* shows potential users that cannot receive a service due to a lack of flow routes linking source and user locations.
For provisioning services, this corresponds to value produced by the environment that cannot be reached by users. For preventive services, it corresponds to damage that could have been inflicted on users but is not due to a lack of flow connections to users.
This map shows homeowners who lack any views due to their lack of flow connections (i.e., living in areas too flat or distant from high quality views).
page.see-also: Aesthetic viewshed and proximity model details from the ARIES website

page.name: Blocked views
page.title: Blocked views
page.description:
*Blocked flow maps* show flow paths that could have delivered an ecosystem service to humans based on the flow routes and source and user locations, but did not because of the action of sinks. These are selected from among all actual flows.
For provisioning services, these flow paths show the loss of possible beneficial service flow to users, and their density is proportional to the value lost. For preventive services, the flow paths show the amount of the total flow that was prevented by natural features from causing damage.
This map shows flows of views as aesthetic information toward homeowners that are blocked by visual blight.
page.see-also: Aesthetic viewshed and proximity model details from the ARIES website

page.name: Degraded natural beauty
page.title: Degraded natural beauty
page.description:
*Blocked use maps* show users that would have received a service carrier based on source and flow dynamics, but did not because of the action of sinks.
For provisioning services, the map shows possible value that were prevented by sinks from reaching users; for preventive services, it shows actual value accrued by users from sinks that blocked damaging flows. For preventive services, therefore, this map is the ultimate quantification of value given the locations and quantity of users and sink features.
This map shows sources of views that are blocked by the presence of visual blight.
page.see-also: Aesthetic viewshed and proximity model details from the ARIES website

page.name: Homeowners with degraded views
page.title: Homeowners with degraded views
page.description:
*Blocked use maps* show users that would have received a service carrier based on source and flow dynamics, but did not because of the action of sinks.
For provisioning services, the map shows possible value that were prevented by sinks from reaching users; for preventive services, it shows actual value accrued by users from sinks that blocked damaging flows. For preventive services, therefore, this map is the ultimate quantification of value given the locations and quantity of users and sink features.
This map shows homeowners who would receive benefits from views but have their views degraded by visual blight.
